hypothesis: This study aims to determine the impact of preprints and EarthArXiv on the speed of academic work dissemination and openness in the Earth sciences community.
supportingArguments: Preprints increase accessibility and speed up the reuse of academic work, as evidenced by rapid citations and social media discussions.
In its first year, EarthArXiv accepted ~500 submissions with total ~60,000 downloads, indicating a move towards openness in Earth sciences.
researchOpportunities: Future studies could explore the impact of preprints on underrepresented sub-disciplines and how they could encourage broader participation.
methodology: EarthArXiv uses a moderation policy to screen submissions for scholarly content. Submitted preprints are assigned a DOI for tracking and citability. Manuscripts can be tagged by discipline and linked with peer-reviewed DOIs.
results: EarthArXiv currently hosts over 500 submissions, with 235 having a second DOI indicating peer-reviewed publication. The platform averages 10 new submissions per week and 2763 monthly downloads.
conclusions: The increasing submission rate and engagement with EarthArXiv highlight an embrace of preprints by the Earth science community, suggesting a shift towards open access dissemination.
limitations: A limitation of this study is the potential underestimation of non-peer-reviewed manuscripts as not all authors report subsequent journal-assigned DOIs.
futureDirections: Future work should investigate how to increase representation of underrepresented sub-disciplines on EarthArXiv and promote the citation of preprints.
keyFindings: EarthArXiv's rapid growth and substantial download statistics demonstrate that the Earth science community is actively participating in preprint dissemination and open access.
